questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with congenital sensorineural hearing loss, recurrent episodes of vertigo, and a palpable thyroid gland. The child's mother has a similar history. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pendred syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • Pendred syndrome is characterized by a combination of congenital sensorineural hearing loss, recurrent vertigo, and the presence of a palpable thyroid gland.
  • The family history of similar symptoms in the mother further supports this diagnosis, indicating autosomal recessive inheritance.

 

Clinical Features of Pendred syndrome:

  • Sensorineural Hearing Loss: Typically congenital and can be progressive.
  • Vertigo: Recurrent episodes due to vestibular dysfunction.
  • Euthyroid Goiter: A goiter present with normal thyroid function (Euthyroidism).
  • Metabolic Alkalosis: Sometimes observed due to associated acid-base balance abnormalities.

questions.text: Identify the below technique used during the examination of the thyroid gland.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lahey’s method

 

Explanation:

  • In Lahey's method, the examiner places the fingers of one hand on the patient’s neck to support the thyroid gland, while the other hand palpates the gland’s surface to assess its size, texture, and any nodules.
  • This technique helps in assessing the consistency and mobility of the thyroid gland, which are important for diagnosing conditions like goiter or thyroid nodules.

 

In Kocher’s method, slight pressure is applied to the lateral lobes of the thyroid gland to evaluate the impact of thyroid swelling on the trachea. A positive test indicates that thyroid swelling is compressing the trachea, leading to stridor (Option A)

 

In Crile’s method, the examiner places a thumb on the swelling and asks the patient to swallow. This technique is used to assess the nodularity of the thyroid swelling. As the patient swallows, the movement of the thyroid gland can help in evaluating the presence and extent of nodules (Option C)

Pizillo’s method is used in patients with an obese or short neck where visual inspection of the thyroid gland is difficult. The patient places their hand behind their head and pushes backwards against the clasped hands on the occiput, improving the visibility and accessibility of the thyroid gland for examination (Option D)

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presents with a solitary thyroid swelling. On examination, a 3 cm non-tender thyroid nodule is noted, and her thyroid function tests are normal. What is the next step in the investigation of this thyroid swelling?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) USG of thyroid

 

Explanation: Ultrasound (USG) is the primary investigation for any thyroid nodule. A reassuring appearance on ultrasound can reduce the need for Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC): Investigation of choice (IOC)  

 



Management of solitary thyroid nodule:

 

Benign nodule
  • For a Cystic nodule: Aspiration - Recurrence - Hemithyroidectomy.
  • For a solid nodule: Thyroxine - Persistent compressive symptoms -Hemithyroidectomy.

Malignancy

Near / Total thyroidectomy

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is a contraindication for radioactive iodine therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Medullary thyroid carcinoma

Explanation: In medullary thyroid carcinoma (TSH independent tumor), the thyroid follicular cells don't take up iodine and hence radioactive iodine has no role.

 

 

Radioactive iodine therapy can serve three primary roles:

  • Remnant Ablation: Destruction of any remaining benign thyroid tissue following a total or subtotal thyroidectomy.
  • Adjuvant Therapy: Additional treatment post-surgery to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence.
  • Treatment of Known Disease: Targeting and destroying residual cancer cells or recurrent structural or biochemical disease.

 

Indications

Contraindications
  • Differentiated thyroid cancers

E.g., Papillary thyroid carcinoma (Option B)

Follicular thyroid carcinoma

Hurthle cell carcinoma (Option C)

  • Tumor size > 2 cm (Option D)
  • One or more risk factors
  • Obvious extrathyroidal extension
  • > 45 years of age
  • Lymph node and distant metastasis (Option D)
  • Poorly differentiated thyroid cancers

E.g., Medullary thyroid carcinoma

Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma

  • Pregnancy & Breastfeeding (Absolute contraindications)
  • Vomiting & Diarrhea (Relative contraindications)

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents with symptoms of weight loss, palpitations and eye protrusion. Lab tests reveal ￬ TSH and ￪  T3, T4 values. What is the most likely diagnosis and the primary target of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Graves disease, TSH receptor

 

Explanation:

  • Symptoms such as weight loss, palpitations, and eye protrusion, combined with low TSH and elevated T3 and T4 levels, indicate Graves disease, an autoimmune disorder.
  • In this condition, antibodies (long acting thyroid stimulator (LATS) target and bind to the TSH receptor.

 

 


 

Toxic multinodular goitre causes hyperthyroidism due to autonomously functioning nodules; the primary target is not the TSH receptor (Option A)

 

Hashimoto's Thyroiditis is an autoimmune hypothyroid condition targeting TPO (thyroid peroxidase), presenting with high TSH and low T3/T4 (Option C)

 

Subacute Thyroiditis follows a viral infection, causing transient hyperthyroidism with elevated thyroglobulin; not associated with eye protrusion (Option D)

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with Graves disease has been receiving medical management for 6 months but continues to have significant symptoms and persistent ophthalmopathy. The goitre remains large. Considering her ongoing symptoms, what is the most appropriate next step in her treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Thyroidectomy

 

Explanation: Thyroidectomy is a suitable next step for patients with persistent symptoms and a large goiter not responding adequately to medical management.

 

 

 

  • Radioactive Iodine (RAI) Ablation is contraindicated in: Pregnancy, Lactation, Patient with eye signs (worsens Ophthalmopathy) (Option B)
  • Antithyroid medications and beta-blockers (Option C): Given the patient's persistent symptoms despite six months of treatment, continuing these medications is unlikely to resolve the issue effectively.
  • External Beam Radiotherapy is not typically used as the primary treatment of thyrotoxicosis (Option D)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with neck pain, fever, and fatigue. His physical examination shows a tender, swollen thyroid gland. Lab reports revealed elevated inflammatory markers and low radioactive iodine uptake, and he is HLA B35 positive. What is the most appropriate initial treatment step for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) NSAIDs

 

Explanation: The clinical presentation and diagnostic findings strongly indicate De Quervain’s thyroiditis (subacute or granulomatous thyroiditis), in which NSAIDs are used as first-line treatment.

 

De Quervain’s Thyroiditis/Viral thyroiditis/ Granulomatous thyroiditis:

  • Often follows a viral upper respiratory tract infection.
  • Initial Brief Hyperthyroidism due to follicular destruction followed by Hypothyroidism, which returns to an Euthyroid state in a few months. (Self Limiting)
  • Associated with HLA B35
  • IOC: FNAC
  • Clinical Features:
    • Neck Pain and Tenderness.
    • Symptoms of Hyperthyroidism and Hypothyroidism depend upon stage.
  • Diagnosis: 
    • Raised inflammatory markers
    • Radioiodine uptake low: Due to follicle destruction.
  • Management: Self Limiting Condition
    • NSAIDs: First-line treatment to control pain and inflammation.
    • Steroids: Used if NSAIDs are ineffective
    • Levothyroxine: Given only during the Hypothyroid phase (Option B is ruled out)

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a known history of Graves' disease presents with signs of thyroid storm i.e., fever, delirium, tachycardia, and restlessness. In addition to beta-blockers and antithyroid drugs, she is started on glucocorticoids. What is the primary rationale for administering glucocorticoids in the management of thyroid storm?

choices.text: To block the conversion of T4 to T3
To suppress the synthesis of thyroid hormones
To reduce the effects of catecholamines
To block the release of T4 and T3

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) To block the conversion of T4 to T3

 

Explanation: 

  • Glucocorticoids act by inhibiting the conversion of T4 to T3, thus reducing the metabolic effects of excess thyroid hormone and offering adrenal support during the crisis.
  • Thyroid storm is a life-threatening exacerbation of hyperthyroidism that requires urgent hospital management due to its high mortality risk.

 

Management of Thyroid storm
  • Oxygen supplementation
  • IV fluids (with continuous monitoring with central venous catheter)
  • Stop IV fluids/blood transfusion in case of CHF or arrhythmias

Propylthiouracil
  • This is the drug of choice
  • It acts by blocking the thyroid hormone synthesis & inhibiting peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 (Option B)
  • ROA: NG Tube, rectal route
  • Methimazole can be used as an alternative option instead of Propylthiouracil

Beta-blockers
  • Propranolol is commonly used
  • It reduces the heart rate & the effects of catecholamines (Option C)
  • Esmolol is used in case of heart failure as Propranolol should be avoided in such conditions

Glucocorticoids
  • Hydrocortisone is preferred
  • It acts by inhibiting the conversion of T4 to T3
  • It helps in preventing adrenal crisis

Lugol solution
  • It blocks the release of T3 and T4 and to reduce the vascularity of the thyroid (Option D)
  • It is also used preoperatively to prevent thyroid storms by inducing the Wolff-Chaikoff effect.

Cholestyramine

It is used to help sequester thyroid hormones.

Chlorpromazine

Used to induce sedation.

Plasmapheresis, charcoal plasma perfusion, or exchange transfusion are reserved for refractory cases that do not respond to standard treatment within 24 to 48 hours.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with a midline neck mass that has been present since childhood and gradually increased in size. On examination, the mass moves upwards with a tongue protrusion. An ultrasound confirms a cystic lesion in the midline of the neck. Given the clinical presentation and imaging findings, which statements are true?

choices.text: High risk of developing squamous cell carcinoma
Removal of the cyst along with the tract and part of the hyoid bone is done
Most commonly seen in the suprahyoid region
Incision and Drainage are the preferred management

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Removal of the cyst along with the tract and part of the hyoid bone is done

 

 

Explanation: The clinical presentation and image classically suggest a Thyroglossal cyst, which is managed by removing the cyst along with the tract up to the base of the tongue and part of the hyoid bone (SISTRUNK Procedure) to minimize the recurrence.

 

Thyroglossal Cyst:

  • It is a congenital neck mass resulting from the persistence of the thyroglossal duct, an embryological structure. It can also be present in adulthood.
  • The cyst represents a remnant of this duct and can be found anywhere along the midline from the base of the tongue to the thyroid isthmus.
  • It presents as midline swelling that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue.
  • Most Common Site: Subhyoid (Option C)

 

Treatment:

  • Sistrunk Procedure: Complete surgical excision of the cyst and its tract up to the base of the tongue, as well as a portion of the hyoid bone, to prevent recurrence.
  • Incision and drainage are never done (Option D) as they lead to the formation of a Thyroglossal fistula. (It also forms if an inflamed cyst ruptures.)—Always Acquired.

 

Long-standing thyroglossal cyst -  > Risk of developing into Papillary thyroid carcinoma. (Option A)

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with multinodular goitre is being treated with a large dose of iodine. Subsequently, his thyroid function tests show significantly elevated TSH and low free T4 levels, but he is asymptomatic. What is the most likely finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Wolff-Chaikoff effect

 

Explanation:

  • The above case, showing raised TSH and reduced T4 levels, is suggestive of hypothyroidism. In this patient, despite adequate iodine intake, hypothyroidism has developed due to iodine-induced suppression of thyroid hormone synthesis, a phenomenon known as the Wolff–Chaikoff effect.
  • The Wolff-Chaikoff effect is characterized by temporary inhibition of thyroid hormone synthesis in response to excess iodine.
  • In individuals with preexisting thyroid conditions, such as multinodular goiter, a high dose of iodine can lead to reduced synthesis of thyroid hormones, causing elevated TSH levels and low free T4 levels, even in the absence of symptoms.

 

Jod- Basedow effect occurs when excess iodine induces hyperthyroidism in individuals with pre existing thyroid disease, typically causing elevated thyroid hormones (Option A)

questions.text: A 31-year-old female with Graves' disease who underwent total thyroidectomy now presents with hoarseness of voice and stridor due to recurrent laryngeal nerve injury. What is the most common site of injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve?

choices.text: At the level of the zuckerkandl tubercle
At the level of the cricothyroid muscle

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Near the inferior thyroid artery

 

Explanation:

  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) due to its anatomical location runs in close proximity to inferior thyroid artery, which makes it vulnerable during dissection or ligation of the artery during thyroidectomy.
  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve, divides into the right and left recurrent laryngeal nerves. It originates from the sixth branchial arches, below the sixth aortic arches.
    • Left Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve: Loops around the ligamentum arteriosum and travels along the tracheoesophageal groove to reach the thyroid gland.
    • Right Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve: Follows a direct path from the vagus nerve to the larynx due to the absence of a normal right subclavian-carotid junction in embryonic development.

Injury to the RLN can result in hoarseness, aphonia, stridor, and aspiration.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with worsening shortness of breath and difficulty swallowing. On physical examination, a large, firm, and non-tender neck swelling is noted. The lower limit of the swelling cannot be palpated, and raising his arms above his head results in the finding shown in the image. Given these clinical findings, which of the following is the Investigation of choice?

choices.text: CT Scan of the Neck and Chest

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) CT Scan of the Neck and Chest

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario, along with a neck swelling whose lower limit cannot be palpated along with a positive Pemberton Sign, points towards Retrosternal Goiter in which Computed Tomography (CT) Scan of the Neck and Chest is the Investigation of choice (IOC).

 

Retrosternal Goiter:

  • A thyroid gland enlargement that extends into the mediastinum behind the Sternum (>50% of thyroid tissue located below thoracic cavity).
  • Types:
    • Primary: Ectopic thyroid tissue in the mediastinum (10%)
    • Secondary: Starts from neck and extends retrosternally (90%)
  • Clinical Features:
    • Neck Swelling with Compression Symptoms: Difficulty breathing (tracheal compression) and swallowing (esophageal compression).
    • Pemberton Sign: Facial flushing and increased difficulty breathing when raising the arms due to thoracic inlet compression.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Physical examination: Limited palpation of the lower border of the thyroid swelling.
    • Imaging: Computed Tomography (CT) Scan of the Neck and Chest is IOC to assess the extent of mediastinal involvement and to evaluate compression of surrounding structures.
  • Management: Surgical intervention and the approaches are
    • Primary / Recurrent / Large Malignant Retrosternal Goiter - Median Sternotomy
    • Secondary Retrosternal Goiter - Cervical / Neck Incision

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman with a large multinodular goitre is scheduled for a total thyroidectomy. To prepare her for the surgery and reduce the risk of complications, her endocrinologist prescribed Lugol's iodine. Which of the following statements are true regarding Lugol's iodine?


	It is used to reduce thyroid vascularity before thyroid surgery
	It works by inhibiting the synthesis of thyroid hormones in the thyroid gland
	It increases the uptake of radioactive iodine
	It is not commonly indicated in the management of toxic multinodular goiter
	It is not indicated in case of a thyroid storm.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1,2,4

 

Explanation:

  • The primary role of Lugol's iodine in the pre-operative management of a patient with a goitre is to reduce thyroid gland vascularity. (Statement 1)
  • Lugol’s Iodine is a Saturated Potassium Iodide Solution (5% iodine + 10% potassium iodide)
  • Dose: 3 drops TID for 7-10 days.

 

Role of Lugol’s Iodine:

  • Reduce Vascularity: Used pre-operatively to reduce the vascularity of the thyroid gland. This helps in minimizing bleeding during surgery and prevents complications.
  • Prevent Thyroid Storm: By decreasing vascularity, it also helps prevent thyroid storms, which can occur if there is an excessive release of thyroid hormones during or after surgery. (Statement 5)
  • Iodine's Effect: Iodine has a transient effect on thyroid function by inhibiting the release of thyroid hormones from the thyroid gland (Statement 2). This phenomenon is known as the Wolff-Chaikoff effect.
    • In Toxic Multinodular Goiter, Lugol's iodine may not achieve the goal of temporary euthyroidism, and instead may exacerbate hyperthyroidism due to the Jod-Basedow phenomenon. (Statement 4)

 

It Increases the uptake of radioactive iodine (Statement 3): Lugol's iodine does not increase radioactive iodine uptake; rather, it prepares the thyroid gland for surgery by reducing vascularity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with an enlarging, hard, and fixed thyroid mass, neck discomfort, and difficulty swallowing. On examination, the thyroid gland feels rock-hard with no tenderness. Ultrasound of the thyroid shows extensive fibrosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Riedel’s Thyroiditis

 

Explanation: Riedel’s thyroiditis (Fibrosing Thyroiditis) is the most likely diagnosis, given the hard/woody thyroid, fixed thyroid mass, absence of tenderness, and ultrasound findings of extensive fibrosis.

 

Riedel’s Thyroiditis (Fibrosing Thyroiditis):

  • Replacement of thyroid tissue with fibrous tissue. There is both intrathyroidal as well as extrathyroidal fibrosis.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Permanent hypothyroidism and hypoparathyroidism.
    • Stridor, with positive Berry's sign (absence/impalpable carotid pulsation).
    • Hard, woody thyroid gland compresses midline structures:
  • Trachea: Causes dyspnea.
  • Esophagus: Causes dysphagia.
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve: Causes hoarseness of voice.

Features

(Option C)

Thyroiditis

Also Known As

  • Granulomatous Thyroiditis

Fibrosing Thyroiditis

Silent thyroiditis is a form of subacute thyroiditis that is usually painless. It presents with transient thyroid dysfunction (hyperthyroidism followed by hypothyroidism) and is generally less associated with a hard and fixed thyroid mass (Option D)

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman in her first trimester is diagnosed with Graves disease. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Propylthiouracil

 

Explanation: Propylthiouracil (PTU) is the drug of choice during the first trimester of pregnancy for treating hyperthyroidism due to its safety profile in early pregnancy.

 

 

Drug

Preferred Age Group

Clinical consideration

Propylthiouracil

Safe in the first trimester and for children; risk of liver toxicity.

Carbimazole

Beta Blockers (e.g., Propranolol)

questions.text: A 23-year-old female visited the clinician with a solitary thyroid nodule and was advised for thyroid function tests where Tsh level is 27.3mU/L, T3 is 1.24 ng/ml, and T4 is 4.87 microgram/ml. Which of the following manifestations is true regarding the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Weight gain

 

Explanation:

  • The patient’s thyroid function tests show elevated TSH with normal T3 and T4 levels, indicating primary hypothyroidism.
  • Weight Gain is consistent with hypothyroidism due to reduced metabolic rate.
  • Heat Intolerance (Option A), Tachycardia (Option B), and Diarrhea (Option C) are more common in hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with a solid, hypoechoic thyroid nodule. She undergoes Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC), which confirms the nodule is benign. What is the most appropriate Bethesda classification and its management for this benign thyroid nodule?

choices.text: Bethesda II; Clinical and sonographic follow-up
Bethesda VI; Repeat FNA, molecular testing or lobectomy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bethesda II; Clinical and sonographic follow-up


 

Explanation: Benign nodules are Bethesda II, and the management is Clinical and sonographic follow-up

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with a thyroid mass and normal thyroid function tests. Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC) is planned to evaluate the mass. Which of the following conditions is FNAC effective in diagnosing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Solitary Thyroid Nodule

 

Explanation: FNAC is the investigation of choice for Solitary thyroid nodules.

 

Limitations of FNAC:

  • Follicular Neoplasms: FNAC cannot differentiate between follicular adenoma and follicular carcinoma because it does not provide information about the capsule or vascular invasion. Further biopsy is needed for a definitive diagnosis. (Option A)
  • Riedel’s Thyroiditis: In this, the thyroid gland is replaced by fibrous tissue, which can result in a poor yield of cells, reducing the effectiveness of FNAC. (Option B)
  • Thyroid Lymphoma: FNAC may not provide sufficient information to diagnose thyroid lymphoma accurately. A biopsy is required to obtain tissue samples for specific markers and a more comprehensive diagnosis. (Option C)
  • Classification of FNAC reports:

 

Thy 1

Thy 1c

Non diagnostic cystic

Thy 2

Non neoplastic

Thy 3

Follicular

Thy 4

Thy 5

Malignant

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of multinodular goitre is being considered for thyroid surgery. The surgical team decides to perform a procedure that removes the majority of the thyroid gland, leaving a small amount of tissue in one of the lobes and removing the isthmus. Which of the following best describes this procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Dunhill Procedure

 

Explanation: The procedure described fits the description of the Dunhill procedure, also known as Near-Total Thyroidectomy, which involves removing most of the thyroid gland, including the isthmus, and performing a subtotal lobectomy of one of the lobes while leaving a small portion of thyroid tissue. This is a modification of subtotal thyroidectomy.

 

 


 

Types of Thyroidectomy:

Total Thyroidectomy

(Option A)
  • All visible thyroid tissue is removed 

Subtotal Thyroidectomy

(Option D)
  • 3-4 grams of thyroid tissue is left in each lobe 
  • Only Indication - MNG in Elderly


Near-Total Thyroidectomy (Dunhill Procedure)

4-6 grams of thyroid is left in one lobe + Subtotal Lobectomy


Lobectomy (Hemithyroidectomy)

(Option B)

Removal of one lobe of the thyroid gland + Isthmus

questions.text:
Match the following Thyroid scan images with respective conditions:

 


	
		
			 
			1.
			
			
			A. Graves Disease
			
		
		
			
			 

			2.
			
			
			B. Cold nodule
			
		
		
			 
			3.
			
			
			C. Hot Nodule
			
		
		
			
			 

			4.
			
			
			D. Toxic Multinodular Goiter
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

 

Explanation:

 

 

Normal Thyroid: Uniform uptake

Hot Nodules (Image 1):

  • Increased uptake in specific areas
  • Often benign and indicate hyperfunctioning tissue.
  • Risk of Malignancy: 1-3%

Cold Nodules (Image 4):

  • Reduced uptake in specific areas
  • Risk of Malignancy: 17-20%

Grave’s Disease (Image 2): Increased uptake throughout the thyroid gland, showing heightened overall activity (Diffuse goiter) 

Toxic Multinodular Goiter (Image 3):

  • Multiple areas of varying uptake
  • Some nodules might show increased activity (Hot Nodules)
  • Some might show decreased activity (Cold Nodules)

Thyroiditis (Inflammation of the Thyroid): Decreased uptake throughout the areas of inflammation due to follicular destruction.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with differentiated thyroid cancer has undergone a total thyroidectomy. To target any residual thyroid tissue or cancer cells, she is scheduled for radioactive iodine ablation therapy. Which of the following isotopes of iodine is used for this therapeutic procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Iodine-131 (I-131)

 

Explanation: In a patient with well differentiated thyroid cancer who has undergone total thyroidectomy, to target any residual thyroid tissue or cancer cells, Radioactive Iodine Ablation (RAI) therapy is done. The isotope of choice is Iodine-131 as it provides both the therapeutic beta radiation and the gamma rays necessary for imaging and monitoring. It also has long half life (8 days).
